Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Uncertainty-aware Planning for Robot Navigation in Human Environments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Robots are increasingly being integrated into society, from service robots to autonomous cars. To be both safe and efficient, however, they need to better understand how people navigate in unstructured environments and plan paths that take people's own paths into consideration. The planning methods developed in this project will generate robot paths that satisfy the dual goals of minimizing the robot's risks of collision with people while simultaneously minimizing its expected task completion time. Unique to this work, the robot dynamically estimates how predictable pedestrians are behaving at any point in time and adapts its plans accordingly, automatically taking safer, more conservative, paths when in less predictable situations, and emphasizing efficiency when the situation is more predictable. The ability for robots to autonomously plan and execute safe, efficient paths in human environments will improve their ability to operate in collaboration with humans, especially in crowded situations, such as in factories, schools, hospitals, or malls.

The navigation method developed follows a sense-plan-predict-act loop where robot plans are computed by finding medium-to-long term trajectories that avoid collision with an expected future distribution of likely obstacle states. The goals of this work split into two tasks: The first improves existing pedestrian path-modeling techniques by augmenting the predictions with estimates of uncertainty. This is accomplished through an iterative maximum-likelihood framework. The second task finds robot trajectories that minimize a path-cost function, accounting for both control and collision costs, while respecting robot dynamics. This is done using an iterative, gradient-based trajectory optimization approach. The resulting navigation approach is evaluated in both simulation and on real pedestrian data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Robots are becoming an increasingly important part of our society. In particular, robots are beginning to move into "human spaces", such as our roads, buildings, sidewalks, and even our homes. This move is a vital step for robots to unlock their full potential, but it comes with unique challenges centered around robots needing to be aware of, and plan around the people in their environments. This broader planning problem has many aspects, but the work in this project focuses on two key challenges needed to support this task:  one, understanding where people near the robot are likely to go; and two, planning routes that account for these likely paths. Below, we briefly summarize our accomplishments on each task.

 

Task 1: Human Motion Prediction

Contributions & Intellectual Merit:

Our work on this task builds on a strong existing foundation of motion prediction. However, much of the existing research has looked at where people will go in just the next second or so. In contrast, our work has developed ways to make much longer term predictions based on how people are likely to react to obstacles in their environment. Our work during this grant has focused on building models that can account for the uncertainty of a robot's prediction (e.g., knowing a person may likely turn left or right to avoid an obstacle, but is not likely to keep going straight at the object), and on building predictive models which can account for longer-term goals (e.g., predicting paths someone might take to reach an exit or pick up a series of items).

 

Broader Impact:

In our work, the goal of building these predictive models is to better inform a robot's motion when working around humans. However, there are many other areas which can benefit from these high-quality human motion models. For example, building safety design can be improved by understanding human flow through the buildings. Likewise, stores, shops, and other retail spaces can improve their efficiency by directing routes or placing popular items along the natural paths that our techniques can help identify. This work is also a step towards creating "smart buildings" and "smart cities" that respond to how people move within them in order to optimize predicted future flows.

 

Task 2: Robot Planning in Dynamic Environments

Contributions & Intellectual Merit:

Even with perfect knowledge of future pedestrian predictions, planning in crowded environments is still challenging for a robotic system. This is due in part to the combinatorial explosion of different possible paths the robot might take around all the people in its environment, and also in part to the physical limitations of a robot's motion (e.g., many robots can only move forward in the direction they are facing). Our work on this project focused on providing fast planning techniques that  produce collision free paths for robots in both sparse and semi-crowded environments, all while accounting for the inherent physical constraints on a robot's posible motion (e.g, limits on speed, acceleration, turning radius, etc.). The new methods we developed are very computationally efficient (often running the key update step in a few milliseconds) and provide robots the ability to smoothly and naturally reach their goals in these crowded environments while minimizing risk of collisions.

 

Broader Impact:

The focus of this work was on robot pedestrian interaction, but the central challenge of motion planning for mobile robotics systems in dynamic environments is shared across many domains. For example, the algorithms we developed can be directly applied to multi-robot systems, where multiple robots are working together in a shared environment (e.g., in a robotic warehouse). Here, a robot is working to predict, plan for, and avoid collisions with other robots, rather than people, but the basic approach is the same. Likewise, related areas such as "swarm robotics" or cooperative robot teams face many of the same challenges. Also, robots operating in semi-cooperative environments, such as self-driving cars, can be formulated in a similar way to our approach in this work and can directly benefit from our contributions.
